p: In recent years the science concerning the physical impacts of climate has continued to expand and to disturb. Average global temperatures continue to rise [ 25], apparently in a process more “stepped” than as a trend [ 26] with record average global heat in both El Niño and La Niña years. Loss of ice from both Antarctica and Greenland is increasing and the rate of sea level rise is consequently accelerating [ 27]. Property values in parts of the U.S. East Coast may soon fall, due to sea level rise [ 28]. There is growing concern about more intense rainfall [ 29, 30], fires worsened by heat and drought [ 31], a weakening Gulf Stream [ 32] and increased sinuosity of the jet stream, which can cause unusual cold at lower latitudes, even if the average global temperature is rising [ 33, 34]. The projected trend toward a weaker and poleward-shifted jet stream is also consistent with projections of a significantly increased risk of worsening extreme heat and dryness in the Northern Hemisphere [ 35].
